bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James P. Leake, January 15, 1947

div1.p: Hench writes that he searching for the initial connection between Reed and Carter. He requests permission to borrow the Reed letters in Leake's possession.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James P. Leake, January 15, 1947
div1.opener:
January 15, 1947
Dr. James P. Leake
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
National Institute of Health
Bethesda, Maryland
My dear Doctor Leake:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your recent letter. I had been
hoping to hear from you further. I am anxious to find out about when
and through whom Walter Reed learned of Carter's work. Certain
evidences suggest that Carter's work did not become first known
until Lazear decided that it indicated a factor of intrinsic incu-
bation. In Hemmeter's book “Master Minds of Medicine,” the chapter
on Carter, states that Agramonte, in a personal letter to General
Kean, stated that Reed and the Board did not know of Carter's work
until October, 1900. Obviously this is a mistake as Reed discussed
Carter's paper with Durham and Myers when the latter visited Reed
in July, 1900. The question still remains as to just who first saw
the significance of Carter's paper, Lazear or Reed. I am in no
way trying to belittle the tremendous contribution of Reed--I am
merely trying to get the facts of the whole story.

I understand from Doctor Hewitt that you have some letters
of Walter Reed. I would appreciate it greatly if you would lend
them to me to photostat here; or, if you do not wish to trust them
to registered mail, could I have them photostated there or at least
copied?
I hope that my reprint finally reached you.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
